title: Markus Gisdol
text:
Markus Gisdol (born 17 August 1969) is a German <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and former player who is the manager of Russian club <a href="FC%20Lokomotiv%20Moscow">Lokomotiv Moscow</a>.
Managerial career.
Gisdol had coaching stints at <a href="SG%20Sonnenhof%20Gro%C3%9Faspach">Sonnenhof Großaspach</a>, <a href="SSV%20Ulm%201846%20Fu%C3%9Fball">Ulm 1846</a>, and <a href="TSG%201899%20Hoffenheim">1899 Hoffenheim II</a>. He was the assistant manager at <a href="FC%20Schalke%2004">Schalke 04</a>.
On 2 April 2013, Gisdol replaced <a href="Marco%20Kurz">Marco Kurz</a> at <a href="TSG%201899%20Hoffenheim">1899 Hoffenheim</a>. Gisdol's first match as a manager was a 3–0 win against <a href="Fortuna%20D%C3%BCsseldorf">Fortuna Düsseldorf</a> and he went on to save them from relegation, leading to his full appointment as Hoffenheim's head coach. On 16 April 2015 he renewed his contract when he signed a three-year extension. 
After an unsuccessful start of Hoffenheim's 2015–16 campaign, Gisdol was sacked on 26 October 2015. On 25 September 2016, he replaced <a href="Bruno%20Labbadia">Bruno Labbadia</a> as the head coach of <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a> with a contract running until 30 June 2017. The contract was extended to 2019 on 22 March 2017. After saving Hamburg in the 2016–17 Bundesliga season from relegation, he went on a losing streak and was sacked on 21 January 2018.
On 18 November 2019, he was signed by <a href="1.%20FC%20K%C3%B6ln">1. FC Köln</a>. On 5 August 2020, Gisdol's contract was extended until July 2023. On 11 April 2021, after losing to <a href="1.%20FSV%20Mainz%2005">Mainz 05</a>, Gisdol was removed from his position as head coach.
On 10 October 2021, he was hired by <a href="Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian Premier League</a> club <a href="FC%20Lokomotiv%20Moscow">FC Lokomotiv Moscow</a>.
